titleStmt.title: A true report of all the speciall passages of note lately happened in the Ile of Ree betwixt the Lord Duke of Buckingham his Grace, Generall for the King of England, and Monsieur Thorax, Gouernour of the Fort in the said Ile, as also betwixt the Duke and the French King, likewise the present state of the Rochellers, and of the Kings Armie lying before it. [Novemb. I.] Numb. 40. The continuation of our vveekly newes from the 24. of October to the 2. of Nouember. Containing among the rest these speciall particulars following. Vnto which is added newes from Germany, France, and diuers parts of Christendome. The warlike proceedings of the imperialists, and Danish. The treatie of peace betwixt Poland and Sweden. The Emperours iourney towarde Prage. Besides diuers other matters of moment. Printed by authoritie.

titleStmt.title: A true report of all the speciall passages of note lately happened in the Ile of Ree betwixt the Lord Duke of Buckingham his Grace, Generall for the King of England, and Monsieur Thorax, Gouernour of the Fort in the said Ile, as also betwixt the Duke and the French King, likewise the present state of the Rochellers, and of the Kings Armie lying before it. [Novemb. I.] Numb. 40. The continuation of our vveekly newes from the 24. of October to the 2. of Nouember. Containing among the rest these speciall particulars following. Vnto which is added newes from Germany, France, and diuers parts of Christendome. The warlike proceedings of the imperialists, and Danish. The treatie of peace betwixt Poland and Sweden. The Emperours iourney towarde Prage. Besides diuers other matters of moment. Printed by authoritie.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: A true Report of all the Å¿peciall PaÅ¿Å¿ages of note lately happened in the Ile of Roe, betwixt the Lord Duke of Buckingham his Grace, Generall for the King of England, and MonÅ¿ieur Thorax, Gouernour of the Fort in the Å¿aid Ile, as alÅ¿o betwixt the Duke and the French King, likewiÅ¿e the preÅ¿ent Å¿tate of the Rochellers, and of the Kings Armie lying before it
Numb. 40.
The Continuation of our vveekly Newes from the 24. of October to the 2. of Nouember.
Containing amongst the reÅ¿t theÅ¿e Å¿peciall particulars following.
Vnto which is added Newes from Germany, France, and diuers parts of ChriÅ¿tendome.
The warlike proceedings of the ImperialiÅ¿ts, and DaniÅ¿h.
The Treatie of Peace betwixt Poland and Sweden.
The Emperours Iourney towards Prage.

p.hi: BeÅ¿ides diuers other matters of moment.

div.p: Printed by Authoritie.
LONDON Printed for Nathaniell Butter, 1627.

div.head: A true Report of all the paÅ¿Å¿ages in the Ile of Ree, twixt the Duke of Buckingham his Grace, and MonÅ¿ieur Thorax, Gouernour of the Fort, as alÅ¿o betwixt the Duke, and the French King, and of the Å¿tate of the Rochellers, and the Kings forces lying before it, together with other matters of moment lately hapned there. As it was on Sunday laÅ¿t being the 25. of October, related at White Hall, by a Dutchman that came from thence.
div.p:
ABout twelue dayes Å¿ince it pleaÅ¿ed his Excellencie the Duke of Buckingham to diÅ¿patch a Dutchman with Letters to his MaieÅ¿tie concerning the preÅ¿ent Å¿tate of our Armie, lying now in the Ile of Ree, and before the Fort or Cittadell there, who Å¿aith,
that about three dayes before his comming away, Sir William Bourchier arriued at the Ile with certaine Å¿hips furniÅ¿hed with money and victuals, Å¿afe and well, which gaue great comfort to his Excellencie, hauing long expected to heare from England, in Å¿o much that before his arriuall our Armie was in great diÅ¿treÅ¿Å¿e for want of prouiÅ¿ion and of victuals, and other neceÅ¿Å¿aries, that it was a great queÅ¿tion whether they Å¿hould continue there any longer, or rather giue ouer the further proÅ¿ecution of the action, in regard of thoÅ¿e many extremities that they were brought vnto, hauing beene of a long time not Å¿upplyed from England, whereupon my Lord taking into conÅ¿ideration, the great diÅ¿honour that would redound to the Nation; Å¿aid that he would for his part aduenture himÅ¿elfe to the vttermoÅ¿t perils Fortune could obiect againÅ¿t him, rather then hee would giue ouer Å¿o noble a deÅ¿igne, and did therevpon exhort all his followers and Souldiers to a conÅ¿tant perÅ¿euerance in the action, maugre all the difficulties that might enÅ¿ue Å¿aying that hee would participate of the greateÅ¿t dangers with themeneÅ¿t of his followers, before hee would Å¿uffer the diÅ¿honour that would accrue vpon the declining of Å¿uch an action, and further Å¿aid hee would rather commit himÅ¿elfe and his whole Armie to the releeuing of the Towne of Rochell before he would returne into England with diÅ¿honour, or without the accompliÅ¿hing of the buÅ¿ineÅ¿Å¿e for which he came thither.

For the Å¿tate of the Fort (notwithÅ¿tanding Å¿ome Å¿mall reliefe they lately had obtayned) is Å¿uch that in the iudgement of man, it cannot hold out many dayes, for Å¿ince they haue receiued Å¿ome reliefe, there hath come forth daily by twenties more or leÅ¿Å¿e, poore hunger-Å¿tarued people, which doth demonÅ¿trate the Å¿tate of the reÅ¿t, hauing had (as they report) only a
poore pittance of Bread and Water, for a moneth or fiue weekes together, inÅ¿omuch, that the number in the Fort which they haue remayning for defence, is come from two thouÅ¿and and odde to fiue hundred, and that of late about two dayes before the comming away of this MeÅ¿Å¿enger, a Dutchman comming out of the Fort, and did deliuer to my Lord Duke the Å¿trength of the Fort, and where they were beÅ¿t prouided for defence, what places were weakeÅ¿t, and not able to defend the leaÅ¿t aÅ¿Å¿ault, Å¿hould bee made againÅ¿t them. For in reaÅ¿on, if we conÅ¿ider the compaÅ¿Å¿e of the Fort) being about a mile) the beÅ¿ieged with that number of men cannot mayntaine each worke, with enterchange of freÅ¿h men, as the neceÅ¿Å¿itie of the Å¿iege will require, by which you may gather that they cannot long Å¿ubÅ¿iÅ¿t. BeÅ¿ides my Lord hath taken and doth poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿e, two of the principall out-workes of the Enemie, by which they are able to diÅ¿mount the greateÅ¿t part of their Ordinance, and in Å¿hort time to command Å¿ome other of their beÅ¿t workes, and to giue law vnto them in their owne tro â¢ ches.

Vpon which conÅ¿ideration, together with other information receiued, my Lord called a Councell, and did thereupon reÅ¿olue to aÅ¿Å¿aile them in places of beÅ¿t aduantage, which was to be put in execution immediately vpon the comming away of this MeÅ¿Å¿enger, not doubting (as this MeÅ¿Å¿enger reports) of a happie IÅ¿Å¿ue, and that the Fort before this is in the poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion of the EngliÅ¿h.

For the further hope of reliefe which they may expect from the Mayne, my Lord hath taken Å¿uch care, and hath from Rochell receiued diuers flat bottome
Boates, which are Å¿o linked and chainted together by art, that now it is impoÅ¿Å¿ible that any Å¿uccour Å¿hould be brought in, in the night, as formerly hath beene; now, whereas Å¿ome may obiect againÅ¿t my Lords care in Å¿uffering the Fort thus at Å¿euerall times to be relieued, I anÅ¿wer, that it is not poÅ¿Å¿ible, neither could the wit of man preuent the Å¿ame, if they will venture at all times, and hazard themÅ¿elues, but that Å¿ome of many may Å¿cape in, with Å¿ome Å¿mall prouiÅ¿ion, vnleÅ¿Å¿e wee could guard the Å¿hoare with a Å¿ufficient number of Boates aÅ¿well night, as day, to preuent which they haue now made a Barracado; as aforeÅ¿aid.

The French King did lately Å¿end a MeÅ¿Å¿enger to my Lord to require a faire quarter to bee obÅ¿erued by his Excellency, & did promiÅ¿e the like Å¿hould be obÅ¿erued on his part, wherunto my Lord Å¿ent him this anÅ¿wer, that for his part he would obÅ¿erue all farre quarters with his MaieÅ¿tie by land; but by water, he deÅ¿ired him to pardon him, and Å¿ayd, that by water it might diÅ¿aduanhim, and therefore would keepe no other quarters then he had done hitherto, and which by the Law of Armes he might iuÅ¿tifie with his Honour.

The French King lying with his Armie before Rochell is verie Å¿icke, and doth Å¿uffer much in his Army by Å¿euerall caÅ¿ualties: the new Fort which hee hath lately erected, is much demoliÅ¿hed, and diuerÅ¿e workes belonging to it taken by the R â¢ chellers, beÅ¿ides thoÅ¿e of Rochell are building another Fort againÅ¿t it, which will be a great annoyance to the Kings Armie.

The Duke of Rohan is marching to the ayd of Rochell with 7000. Foot and 500. HorÅ¿e well prouided
and reÅ¿olute Souldiers. In Lorraine, a BiÅ¿hop of that Dukedome hath in readineÅ¿Å¿e 15000. men, which as it is Å¿ayd, are prouided, and haue a purpoÅ¿e to fall vpon Å¿ome parts of the French Kings Dominions, and that the quarrell Å¿hould be the HouÅ¿e of AuÅ¿tria's, beÅ¿ides Å¿ome other Princes are preparing to inuade him likewiÅ¿e, which will giue the French King his hands full.

My L. Duke and his whole Armie are couragious and in good eÅ¿tate, he hath receiued lately fiue companies from Rochell of braue reÅ¿olute fellowes, and hath Å¿ent into Rochell all his Å¿icke and hurt men, where they are well releeued of all neceÅ¿Å¿aries.

The Rochellers haue wholly declared themÅ¿elues for the King of England, as by the Articles which are agreed vpon by my L. Duke and them doth appeare, his Excellencie hath Å¿ent word to his MaieÅ¿tie, that if it pleaÅ¿e him to Å¿end him bread, he will deÅ¿erue it, but if he will adde vnto it Å¿omewhat more he will drinke his health; by which you may Å¿ee his inuincible courage, zeale and affection to his Countries Honour, which I pray God to proÅ¿per.

Since this MeÅ¿Å¿enger came, one MaÅ¿ter Griffin, a Gentle-man belonging to his Excellencie, arriued in London on Sunday night (who being longer at Å¿ea) yet was diÅ¿patcht away before this Dutch-man 12. daies, & doth confirme what this MeÅ¿Å¿enger brought, only it was his misfortune to arriue after him, being croÅ¿t by contrarie winds, and the Barke in which hee came in being caÅ¿t away, and onely himÅ¿elfe and his fellow-paÅ¿Å¿engers were Å¿aued by the mercie of God, together with thoÅ¿e packets and other matters of worth, which they had in
the Å¿aid Barke, were Å¿aued from Å¿hipwracke, and can relate not much more then the former MeÅ¿Å¿enger.

div.head: From Rome the 18. of September.
div.p: ON Satturday laÅ¿t, paÅ¿t a SpaniÅ¿h PoÅ¿t thorow this Citie going to the Vice-Roy of the Kingdome of Naples with an order of the King of Spaine, that hee Å¿hould Å¿end many Ships and Gallies into Spaine, to bee imployed againÅ¿t the EngliÅ¿h.

div.head: From Venice the 24. of September.
div.p: They write from Rauenna, that the haile hath done there great hurt to the Corne, Vines, and Cattell.
About foureteene dayes agoe was here a great tempeÅ¿t with much raine. The Duke of Sauoy hath Å¿ent many Souldiers towards AÅ¿ti, to raiÅ¿e there Å¿ome Sconces.

div.head: From Vienna the 28. of September.
div.p:
The Imperiall Proclamations are here Å¿trictly executed againÅ¿t the ProteÅ¿tants, whoÅ¿e Preachers begin to depart. The Emperour is doing the like both in Styria, Carenthia, and Crain. The ProteÅ¿tants which haue here yet beene Å¿uffered, are compelled to depart from hence, vpon paine of the forfeiture of all their lands and goods,
ãâ¦ã

div.head: THE Continuation of our VVeekly Newes from the 24 of October to the 2 of Nouember.
From Jtaly, Germany, Poland, Swethland, France, the Low-Countries, and diuers other places.
From Rome the 25 of September.
div.p: ON WedneÅ¿day laÅ¿t, paÅ¿t an extraordinary PoÅ¿t, of the Merchants of Genoa through this City, being Å¿ent towards Naples by them, Å¿eeing that the King of Spaine hath tranÅ¿ported vnto them his CuÅ¿tome of Silke which he hath in the Kingdome of Naples, to get thereby the money which hee oweth vnto them.
Here is little newes, Å¿eeing that all the Souldiers which were in theÅ¿e parts leauied, are gone into Germany, to Å¿erue the Emperour, except them which are laid in gariÅ¿on.

div.head: From Vienna the 29 of September.
div.p: On the 26 of this Moneth is his Imperiall MaieÅ¿tie with the EmpreÅ¿Å¿e, the King of Hungarie, and both his daughters, beÅ¿ides many of his Courtiers, gone from hence towards Prage. The Prince his yongeÅ¿t Sonne, and the Archduke Leopoldus tarrie here.
His Imperiall MaieÅ¿tie and all them which are gone with him, are to day to keepe at Nicholas burg in the houÅ¿e of the Cardinall of DidrichÅ¿tein the feaÅ¿t of Saint Michael.

The Duke Iulius Fredericke of Wirtenburg is here daily expected. But it is thought that Å¿eeing that the Emperor is departed that he will reÅ¿t himÅ¿elfe here Å¿ome dayes, and goe afterwards to the Emperor.

To day is expired the time which was prefixed to the ProteÅ¿tant Preachers for their departure. But Å¿eeing that the raine-water, and otherwaters which haue drowned the Land, haue much Å¿poiled the high-wayes, that they cannot well be vÅ¿ed, they haue at their requeÅ¿t obtained leaue to tarry in this Land Å¿ome few weekes to diÅ¿poÅ¿e in the interim of their affayres, and meanes. They are to forÅ¿ake this land before expiration of three weekes, vpon paine to be Å¿euerely puniÅ¿hed.
It is here rumored by many, but belieued by very few, that there a peace concluded betwixt the Emperour and the great Signior for the Å¿pace of 25. yeares.

Herewith I Å¿end the Imperiall Proclamation which hath in this Court by the Clergie beene obtained, and beene printed, and affixed two dayes agoe, and likewiÅ¿e beene Å¿ent to diuers other places, by which is commanded that the Preachers, and Schoole-maÅ¿ters which are ProteÅ¿tants Å¿hall forÅ¿ake the Land of Over-Ens within a certaine time which is prefixed, and that the exerciÅ¿e of their religion Å¿hall neuer any more there be Å¿uffered.

div.head: From BreÅ¿law the 1 of October.
div.p: To day is the Company of Captaine Swank diÅ¿charged which was leauied for this Citie, Å¿o that wee haue now no more then three Companies to entertaine.
Wee haue newes from Thorne that there is not as yet a peace concluded betwixt the Kings of Polon and Sweden.

It continueth not that the Army of Sweden hath bene ouerthrowne by the Poloniuns as they did formerly write from DanÅ¿ick: But it is certaien that there haue been many Å¿laine of each Å¿ide, and that both parties retreated againe to their works, and intrenchments.

The AmbaÅ¿Å¿adors, and CommiÅ¿Å¿ioners meet yet dayly, and it is reported that the SwediÅ¿h propound very hard conditions of peace, namely, that the King of Poland Å¿hould reÅ¿igne for euer for him and his heires the title and claime which hee hath or pretendeth to the Kingdome of Sweden: That the King of Poland Å¿hould giue to the King of Sweden 80 tunnes of gold for the payment of his Å¿ouldiers, and warlike expences: As likewiÅ¿e that the King of Poland Å¿hould Å¿uffer him to enioy for the Å¿pace of tenne yeares all the places which he hath taken in PruÅ¿Å¿ia, and after the expiration of them, hee Å¿hould reÅ¿tore them againe to the Crowne of Poland, beÅ¿ides diuers other difficult points vnto which the King of Poland will not agree.
On Saturday laÅ¿t here was one beheaded before the Towne houÅ¿e, becauÅ¿e he kill'd a Coach-man.
To day is here publiÅ¿hed a Proclamation of the Emperor by which he cauÅ¿eth all the lands and goods to bee confiÅ¿cated of them which went to Å¿erue Count Mansfield in the late warres.

They write from Neus that no ProteÅ¿tants are Å¿uffered there to marry, vnleÅ¿Å¿e they imbrace the RomiÅ¿h Religion. But if they will not doe it, they may Å¿ell their lands, and goods, and depart thence.

div.head: From Venice the 1. of October.
div.p: They write from Millaine that all the Å¿ouldiers of the Lord of Pappenheim are marched through Æ²eltolina into Germanie, and that they of the Count of Solms are Å¿hortly to follow them. The Colonell Piccolomini is likewiÅ¿e paÅ¿t thorow Chur, with 40 horÅ¿e to follow them.

We haue newes from Genoa, that there is a peace concluded betwixt the Duke of Sauoy, & the Å¿aid Signeurie, and that although the Å¿aid Signeurie hath diÅ¿charged Å¿ixe Companies of Italians, that they take neuertheleÅ¿Å¿e Germaines into their Å¿eruice in lieu of them.

We learne from France that the Duke of Momorancy is gathering great forces againÅ¿t the ProteÅ¿tants of France, and that he is appointed to beÅ¿iege the Towne of Nimis, in which the Duke of Rohan is in perÅ¿on: As likewiÅ¿e that they make there great warlike preparations by water againÅ¿t the EngliÅ¿h. Moreouer that the EngliÅ¿h haue Å¿laine, and throwne ouerboard many French men and Å¿ouldiers that were bound for the Iland of St. Martin.

div.head: From DanÅ¿icke the 7. of September.
div.p: On the 24 of AuguÅ¿t after dinner time went the Duke of HolÅ¿tein into the field to looke out for a conuenient place to inquarter his leger (which is Å¿eparated from that of the Polonians) to whom are likewiÅ¿e ioyned the Forces of the two Commanders named Dohnhof â¢ r.

On the 29 of AuguÅ¿t about the euening came the King of Poland with many men of note, and his Courtiers, and followers into this City, and was with great Å¿tate and pompe fetcht into it by our Citizens; and well entertained afterwards by our MagiÅ¿trates.

The day before were the AmbaÅ¿Å¿adours of the States Generall of the Vnited Prouinces of the Low-Counties
which labour very earneÅ¿tly to make peace betwixt Poland and Sweden) gone towards the Polon â¢ an Generall of the Field.

On the firÅ¿t of September went the King of Poland to Å¿ee and to view our walls, and all our Å¿conces, and works round about this City, and eÅ¿pecially the new raiÅ¿ed Å¿conce, which the Å¿ouldiers cal commonly Schenke-Å¿conce, by reaÅ¿on of the Å¿trength of it: and at the Å¿ame time there were 44 peeces of ordnance diÅ¿charged, beÅ¿ides many muskets both by water and land. The King liking theÅ¿e workes exceedingly well, reioyced much at it, and commended much to his Lords the endeauors and faithfulneÅ¿Å¿e of the DanÅ¿ickers, Å¿aying that they had well laboured, and were his loyall Å¿eruants, and that they had not done as they of Elbingen, and others.

On the Å¿econd of September went the King of Poland with the Prince his Å¿onne, and diuers great Lords, beÅ¿ides our BurgemaÅ¿ters, and Å¿ome of our Aldermen, early in the morning toward the Fort which is called WeichÅ¿elmundt, and when they had viewed there all things very well, our MagiÅ¿trates did feaÅ¿t very Å¿tately both the King and his followers, and about the euening there were many pieces of ordnance diÅ¿charged both in the 12 Ships which lay thereabout, and in the Sconces. And it happened that about the Å¿ame time, that a Galley of the King of Poland being put to Sea to try whether it could well Å¿ayle, it encountred with a SwediÅ¿h Å¿hip, and had a pretty combat both with it, and 3 other for a little while, which were afterwards cruelly battered by our ordnance which lay in a Å¿conce neere which the SwediÅ¿h followed the Å¿aid Gally. The Å¿aid King hauing Å¿eene this Å¿port with contentment, returned the Å¿ame euening againe to the Å¿aid City, and departed from thence on the 4 of this moneth, three PoÅ¿tes being Å¿ent to him, and went directly towards his Army.

In the weeke which is laÅ¿t paÅ¿t were the AmbaÅ¿Å¿adors
together, and the Polonians were to propound Å¿ome articles of peace betwixt Poland and Sweden.

div.head: From BrunÅ¿wicke the 2 of October.
div.p: We haue nor as yet any other newes from the Deputations day which is appointed to be kept at MulhowÅ¿en, but that diuers AmbaÅ¿Å¿adors as of the Emperor, Electors, Princes, and States of the Empire, are gone thitherward.

They of Wolfenbuttel although they are very cloÅ¿e imblocked, Å¿ally neuertheleÅ¿Å¿e daily forth, and Å¿lue few dayes agoe many Imperiall Å¿ouldiers and husbandmen that would Å¿top the water which runneth to the Å¿ayd Towne.

The Towne of Newburg, or the Gouernor of it, namely the Colonell Limbach hath offered to Å¿urrender it vpon certaine conditions to the Duke of Lunnenburg, and amongÅ¿t the reÅ¿t, that the Emperour Å¿hould grant a generall pardon to them that are in it. But if that be refuÅ¿ed, he will blow vp the Å¿aid Towne, and ruine all that is therein.

div.head: From Æ²erden the 8 of October.
div.p: Both the Imperiall and DaniÅ¿h Å¿ouldiers make themÅ¿elues daily Å¿tronger and Å¿tronger in this BiÅ¿hopricke. The DaniÅ¿h hauing raiÅ¿ed a Å¿trong Å¿conce at Borcht to maintaine themÅ¿elues there, they haue fired the Towne of Verden, and burned it quite to the ground.

From Newburg we heare no newes, Å¿eeing that the Å¿aid Towne being now very Å¿trictly beÅ¿ieged, the PoÅ¿ts which come from Cullen haue altered their paÅ¿Å¿age, and trauelled by the way of NewÅ¿tadt: But it is thought that it Å¿hall be Å¿urrendred if the Gouernor of it can obtaine a pardon of the Emperor, Å¿eeing that he hath had it twice before.
The ImperialiÅ¿ts make great warlike preparations to beat the DaniÅ¿h quite out of the BiÅ¿hopricke of Bremen of which we Å¿hall Å¿hortly heare more.

div.head: From Stoade the 7 of October.
div.p: This Towne is repleniÅ¿hed with DaniÅ¿h Souldiers, but they are in great feare, Å¿eeing that the ImperialiÅ¿ts Å¿trengthen themÅ¿elues daily in thoÅ¿e parts.

Our BiÅ¿hop who is now at Lubecke, as likewiÅ¿e the Imperiall AmbaÅ¿Å¿adors which are yet at Hamburg, exhort the States of theÅ¿e Lands that they will remember the oath which they haue made to the Emperor.
The DaniÅ¿h lye yet intrenched neere Crimpen, and Lukestadt, and we haue not heard that there hath lately any thing of moment beene done by the ImperialiÅ¿ts or DaniÅ¿h.

div.head: From Pinnenberg the 10 of October.
div.p: We haue not as yet learned any certaintie how it Å¿tandeth with RenÅ¿burg, and with the Imperiall Campe, but we expect it daily.
The Generall Tilly is gone from Lawenburg towards WinÅ¿en, which is a CaÅ¿tle of the Duke of Lunnenburg.
